item.title: dev
item.description:
Monasca is an active OpenStack project and welcomes new developers.

OpenStack Community

Monasca was formally accepted as an official OpenStack project in November, 2015 during the OpenStack Governance Review for Monasca and follows the OpenStack contribution guidelines and code standards.

The Monasca project has a launchpad site which is primarily used for bug tracking and blueprints. The project mailing list is also hosted on launchpad, at the Monasca Launchpad Team.

Monasca hosts weekly meetings in IRC as well as other venues, such as mid-cycle meetups and OpenStack Summits. Details on the team meetings can be found at Monasca Weekly Meeting and the Monasca Wiki.

Code Contributions

Monasca is hosted in Github by the Github OpenStack Organization.

All code is submitted via the OpenStack Gerrit Review System and is under gated tests that include a battery of unit and functional tests using the Monasca DevStack Plugin and Monasca Tempest Tests .

Currently, the Monasca Vagrant environment is the primary development environment for Monasca. The Monasca DevStack Plugin environment is also used as a development environment. More information on testing Monasca can be found at the testing page.

item.title: Testing Monasca
item.description:
As part of OpenStack the primary testing for Monasca is done using the OpenStack testing. Monasca code runs through the standard OpenStack CI. Additionally work to integrate Monasca into tempest is ongoing.

Some additional test scripts used in our test environment including an experimental CI system is available in the Monasca CI repository.

item.title: Vagrant Development Environment
item.description:
The Monasca team has built a Vagrant based development environment which is especially helpful for any development on the server stack of Monasca. This environment and extensive instructions on running it are found at the github repo monasca-vagrant.

The environment installs the latest Monasca code and all dependencies into two VMs. You can then turn off components as needed for development. There are some limitations to this environment, most notably it is a non-HA environment and initial downloads can take awhile.

If you are simply looking for an API endpoint and have no need to develop on the server stack of Monasca another options is to run the Monasca Demo and use its api. This should be simpler to start up and experience less churn with the normal development process.
